moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4
comment: Adams wasn't able to break through this defense in round four, so why not try it again.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6
comment: This is a curious move. It threatens Pe5 which forces White, at least for the moment, to leave Nf3, which blocks Pf2 from advancing. Also, it prevents Bc1-f4 and clears the way for Bf8 to develop. I suppose Black decides how to develop his king-side pieces depending upon where White develops Bc1. If b2-b3, Bc1-b2 then Bf8 probably has to remain in place for a while to defend Pg7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7
comment: This seems to end Black's cramp and White's chances to play for a win. But, perhaps I'm overestimating it's importance. White still has the king-side pawn majority and safer king.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7 Kxe7 14. Nd4 Nf4

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7 Kxe7 14. Nd4 Nf4 15. Ne4 Rd8 16. Rfe1 Rd5 17. c4 Rd8 18. Kh2 a5 19. g4 a4 20. Kg3 Ne6 21. Nf5+ Kf8 22. f4 b6 23. Rxd8+ Nxd8 24. Ne3 Ne6 25. f5
comment: White has achieved a lot. To get this far is significant. The next step is usually some key invasion which pins a piece or attacks two targets when the defender can't maneuver his pieces because they have no squares or are busy defending one another.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7 Kxe7 14. Nd4 Nf4 15. Ne4 Rd8 16. Rfe1 Rd5 17. c4 Rd8 18. Kh2 a5 19. g4 a4 20. Kg3 Ne6 21. Nf5+ Kf8 22. f4 b6 23. Rxd8+ Nxd8 24. Ne3 Ne6 25. f5 Nd4 26. Kf4 Bb7 27. c5 a3 28. b3
comment: After this (good move) Black begins to envisage ...Nd4xb3; axb3 a3-a2; and ...Bb7-a6-d3-b1 to allow a2-a1=Q or if White has placed Rd1-a1 to trap it, so Ra8 can be unopposed. This plan is merely an idea at this point, and hardly enforcable, but something to work toward. White, will have to avoid that and still find a way to break through Black's queen-side; where he's been holding Black in place and now hopes to hit hard.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7 Kxe7 14. Nd4 Nf4 15. Ne4 Rd8 16. comment: Black might use ...Nd4-e2+ to chase Kf4 back

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Nxe4 5. d4 Nd6 6. Bxc6 dxc6 7. dxe5 Nf5 8. Qxd8+ Kxd8 9. Nc3 Ne7 10. h3 Ng6 11. Bg5+ Ke8 12. Rad1 Be7 13. Bxe7 Kxe7 14. Nd4 Nf4 15. Ne4 Rd8 16. Rfe1 Rd5 17. c4 Rd8 18. Kh2 a5 19. g4 a4 20. Kg3 Ne6 21. Nf5+ Kf8 22. f4 b6 23. Rxd8+ Nxd8 24. Ne3 Ne6 25. f5 Nd4 26. Kf4 Bb7 27. c5 a3 28. b3 Ba6 29. cxb6 cxb6 30. Nd6
comment: This gives Kf4 another square near the center, to support Pe5.

Nxc4 b5 33. Nd6 f6
comment: Black's ability to undermine every step forward White would like to make is keeping the balance. And, Pa3 has to be watched carefully. If Pa2 is threatened the entire empire is in danger.
